against the organization and personnel of the Expedition, 
Dr Shaw has extracted from the various papers in the book the only four instances in which the procedure 
is alleged to have been peculiar. He implies that 
others exist and repeats a single instance in a fresh 
disguise. 
Of the four allegations, three are made 
in apparent ignorance of the conditions of life in the 
Antarctic Regions and one only is capable of limited 
substantiation. 
I wish next to call your attention to Dr 
Shaw's remarks on page X11 under the heading "pressure 
and Winds" and more especially to Paragraph 111 et seq 
in which he describes the failure of two crucial tests 
to determine the barometric gradient. 
Dr Shaw practically states that the first 
test fails because there is a doubt as to whether 
the winds were recorded as 'magnetic' or 'true' on 
Lieutenant Royds' journey across the Barrier. 
This statement is made in site of the 
following facts. 
Lieutenant Royds definitely informed Dr Shaw 
that all wind directions recorded whilst the the "Discovery" 
was in Winter Quarters were 'true' unless otherwise 
noted. 
Mr Bernacchi was the only other Officer who 
went on this journey; he informs me he was not consulted
